qas.question: What is one common result of using antibiotics from a young age?
What are some antibiotics can be used for STAT?

answers.text: penicillin, vancomycin, penicillin and vancomycin, or chlortetracycline

qas.question: Do antibiotics cause obesity in humans?
Why do physicians use antibiotics on infants when the relationship has been proven?
What can happen if people are exposed to antibiotics at a young age?
Do antibiotics increase the chance of getting fat for humans?
What is one common result of using genes from a young age?

plausible_answers.text: penicillin, vancomycin, penicillin and vancomycin, or chlortetracycline

qas.question: What are some microbiota that can be used for STAT?
Do antibiotics cause fasting in humans?
Why do physicians use antibiotics on mice when the relationship has been proven?

context: Exposure to antibiotics early in life is associated with <a0_0><a5_0><b8_0>increased body mass<b8_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/> in humans and mouse models. <a6_0><b12_0>Early life<b12_0/><a6_0/> is a critical period for the establishment of the intestinal microbiota and for metabolic development. Mice exposed to <a1_0>subtherapeutic antibiotic treatment<a1_0/> (STAT)– with either <a2_0><b9_0>penicillin, vancomycin, penicillin and vancomycin, or chlortetracycline<b9_0/><a2_0/> had altered composition of the gut microbiota as well as its metabolic capabilities. Moreover, research have shown that mice given low-dose penicillin (1 μg/g body weight) around birth and throughout the weaning process had an increased body mass and fat mass, accelerated growth, and increased hepatic expression of genes involved in adipogenesis, compared to controlled mice. In addition, penicillin in combination with a high-fat diet increased fasting insulin levels in mice. However, it is <a3_0><a7_0>unclear<a7_0/><a3_0/> whether or not antibiotics cause obesity in humans. Studies have found a correlation between early exposure of antibiotics (<6 months) and increased body mass (at 10 and 20 months). Another study found that the type of antibiotic exposure was also significant with the highest risk of being overweight in those given macrolides compared to penicillin and cephalosporin. Therefore, there is correlation between antibiotic exposure in early life and obesity in humans, but whether or not there is a causal relationship remains <b10_0>unclear<b10_0/>. Although there is a correlation between antibiotic use in early life and obesity, the effect of antibiotics on obesity in humans needs to be <a4_0><b11_0>weighed against the beneficial effects<b11_0/><a4_0/> of clinically indicated treatment with antibiotics in infancy.
